item.title: Dataday Texas 2020 - A Few Quick Notes
item.description: With downtime during pandemic-imposed social distancing, I’m returning to reflect on my experience at Dataday Texas 2020. After moving to Austin in 2019, I was pleasantly surprised to see the data-focused event less than a mile from my apartment. The 2 key themes I took away from the talks I attended were: Open-source business models are becoming less sustainable due to pressure from cloud providers. A trend bringing ML to databases for “Tunables” Evolution of Open-Source and Open-Core Models I was not expecting the level of distaste for Amazon among the speakers.

item.title: Reading List
item.description: Currently Reading Data and Reality Madame Bovary On Deck An Elegant Puzzle - Systems of Engineering Management The Gulag Archipelago 2020 Favorites A Gentleman in Moscow 2019 Favorites Designing Data-Intensive Applications Managing the Professional Services Firm Ham on Rye War and Peace Anna Karenina Favorite Blogs Ribbonfarm Farnam Street 2018 Favorites Skin in the Game The Elephant in the Brain: Hidden Motives in Everyday Life Zorba the Greek Where’d You Go, Bernadette Brothers Karamazov 2017 Favorites The Dao of Capital Certain to Win Sapiens Man’s Search for Meaning Death’s End Siddartha Foundation Trilogy Infinite Jest Homo Deus

item.title: A Basic Teradata SQL-Mode for Emacs
item.description: Lately I have been learning emacs and building out a development workflow. I wanted a seamless experience querying Teradata during develpement. I’m typically working on shell scripts that use sql through either bteq or tpt. Code Here is what I wrote up extending the sql-mode package. This is loaded in my init.el file with (load "my-path/teradata.el"). This requires bteq to be installed and in the path. This has been tested on Windows.

item.title: Python Requests Api
item.description: Recently I have been writing a lot of code to generate flat file extracts from REST apis. This task is relatively straightforward, but can be quite time consuming if not approached in the correct manner. In this post I have put together a simple example pipeline for quickly generating an extract using Python with the requests library. The goal is to be able to have a flat file extract ready to analyze in an hour or less.

item.title: OMSCS Prep
item.description: I will be starting the Georgia Tech OMSCS program this fall. It has been a while since I’ve been in school, so I put together a simple refresher course based on the feedback from reddit, google+, and omscentral. Hopefully my thought process can be helpful to others. Obviously preparation will vary depending on individual goals and background. I’ll update early in the first semester with feedback and what I wish I would have known.

item.title: Fitbit Data
item.description: A Fitbit collects an incredible amount of granular data on personal activity, heart rate, and sleep. However, currently most of the detailed data is locked up within the app. This tutorial shows a simple way to extract the heart rate data in an automated fashion. This code will generate ‘personal data extracts’ according to simple specifications, without requiring any copy pasting or manual effort beyond the initial configuration. Many others have posted helpful tutorials on this topic.
